Snip

First one. I think the first one looks more realistic, on the second one you can see where the OMS pods start with the nosecones on the front.

Wait, while typing this I realized how the engines are still angled while the actual pods are still straight. This is a tough decision. The RCS setup on the new one is also better in that it extrudes from the back.

How many more parts is it? Odysseus STS is already an amazingly low part count for what it is, not sure which to choose.

Edited February 25, 2014 by Giggleplex777

Testing the vernier motors.

Very slow, but they work.

I always liked it since the day you first posted it, but tbh, I never felt the need to download it. It was just a nice little craft to look at.

I've always felt like I should design my own stuff, because using other people's stuff feels like using someone's toothbrush, so I tried designing my own shuttle with a couple of mods.

It didn't work.

Eventually, I gave up and downloaded your shuttle, but just so I could see how you built it. Oh man, how I wish I would have downloaded it earlier.

That thing you see there is an eve probe with a kick stage, massing a whooping 2.4t. With about 2300 ÃŽâ€v, it had more than enough to set the probe on an impact trajectory, after which it would land using a parachute.

It flew perfectly in the first flight, and still had lots of fuel for deorbiting. That means it's idiot-proof.

Unfortunately, I messed up the deorbit burn and ended up coming short of the KSC, and instead of reloading the quicksave I had made just before deorbiting, I accidentally reverted to the VAB... So now there's no STS-1, no Eve probe on it's way, and just a couple of pictures from the non-existent flight.

EDIT: Oh, and sorry for posting so many screenshots. I wish the spoiler tags still worked...

Edited February 28, 2014 by astropapi1

Glad you liked it! There is a parachute, in case you do have to ditch the shuttle.

One problem I had with it was that it glides like a brick, despite having so many lifting surfaces. I think the swept wings the culprits, as they act weirdly when placed sideways.

I always wonder how people get planes (or gliders) to fly so well...

Personally, I feel the Odysseus STS handles well, it has at least some lift to guide it to landing.

Whenever I tried space shuttles I spam lifting surfaces at the back (clipping like 4 on each sides). And yes, it still flies like a brick... Sideways swept wings must be the cause, it's a shame because they make the wings look so good.

The first real mission of Odysseus v2.0, STS-01A. The mission was to install the new solar panels to a space station as well as transfer its over to the station. The shuttle was modified to accommodate the larger RCS tug, which was used to assemble the components.
